review.title: Don't 'have a clue'? Unsupervised co-learning of downward-entailing operators
review.abstract: Researchers in textual entailment have begun to consider inferences involving 'downward-entailing operators', an interesting and important class of lexical items that change the way inferences are made. Recent work proposed a method for learning English downward-entailing operators that requires access to a high-quality collection of 'negative polarity items' (NPIs). However, English is one of the very few languages for which such a list exists. We propose the first approach that can be applied to the many languages for which there is no pre-existing high-precision database of NPIs. As a case study, we apply our method to Romanian and show that our method yields good results. Also, we perform a cross-linguistic analysis that suggests interesting connections to some findings in linguistic typology.

sections.text: We used Rada Mihalcea's corpus of approximately 1.45 million sets of Romanian newspaper articles. Note that we cannot evaluate the impact on textual conclusions because, to our knowledge, there is no publicly available text tracking system or rating data for Romanian. sections.heading: 3.2 Generating a seed set
sections.text: Although, as discussed above, the translation of an NPI need not be an NPI, a preliminary review of the literature indicates that in many languages there is an NPI that can be translated as "arbitrary" or related forms such as "arbitrary." Thus, with little effort, one can form a minimal NPI seed set for the DLD09 method by using an appropriate target language translation of "arbitrary." In Romanian, we used "vreo" and "vreun," the female and male translations of the English "any."

sections.heading: 3.3 DLD09 using the Romanian seed set
sections.text: We will first check whether DLD09 performs well with the bipolar seed set described in paragraph 3.2 in Romanian. In fact, the results are quite poor: the accuracy is, for example, 30% below 50%. (See blue / dark bars in Figure 3 in the externally available appendices for detailed results.) This relatively unsatisfactory performance could be a consequence of the very small size of the NPI list used and could therefore indicate that it would be fruitful to investigate an automatic extension of our reference list.

sections.heading: 3.4 Main idea: a co-learning approach
sections.text: Our main finding is that not only can NPIs be used as a guide to finding DE operators, as shown by DLD09, but vice versa, DE operators (if known) can potentially be used to detect new NPI-like cues that we call pseudo-NPIs (or PNPIs for short periods of time). By "NPI-like," we mean "to serve as possible indicators of the presence of DE operators, regardless of whether they are actually limited to negative contexts, such as real NPIs." For example, the words "allegation" or "rumor" tend to occur mainly in DE contexts, such as "denied" or "dismissed," even though they are clearly not real NPIs. "Given this finding, we are approaching an iterative co-learning paradigm that extends the search for new DE operators.

sections.heading: 4 Romanian results
sections.text: Our results show that there is indeed a favorable synergy between the DE operator and the pNPI retrieval. Figure 2 shows the number of correctly retrieved DE operators in the top k outputs at each iteration. The point at iteration 0 corresponds to a data point already discussed above, namely DLD09, which is applied to the two "arbitrarily" translatable NPIs. Clearly, we see a general significant improvement over DLD09, even if the increases decrease in later iterations. (Determining the optimal number of iterations is the subject of future research.) Further experiments described in the externally available appendices (§ 7.2) suggest that pNPIs may be even more effective clues than a noisy list of NPIs. (Therefore, a larger seed set does not necessarily mean better performance.) pNPIs also have the advantage of being automatically derivable, and may be worth a linguistic examination from your own perspective.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: Previous work on automatic detection of DE operators has assumed the existence of a high-quality collection of NPIs that renders them inapplicable in most languages where such a resource does not exist. We overcome this limitation by using a novel co-learning approach and demonstrate their effectiveness in Romania.We also introduce the concept of pseudo-NPIs. Auxiliary experiments described in the externally available appendices show that pNPIs are actually more effective than a loud "true" NPI list. Finally, we identified some cross-language performance differences and found an interesting link between these differences and haspelmath [9] characterization of cross-language variation when "real" NPIs occur. 10 examples: Chinese, German, Italian, Polish, Serbian.

sections.heading: 7.1 Labeling protocol
sections.text: Following DLD09, system outputs (i.e. candidates for DE operations) were combined with a series of distractors - words that, according to WordNet, are related to the system outputs but not synonymous. We chose distractors that resembled real system outputs so that the distractors did not appear to be "unusual." The combined collection was presented in a random order to two native Romanian speakers (one author, one not) whose task was to designate each element as either "DE," "not DE," or "hard," meaning "hard to decide," and to justify their choice by providing a follow-up example of the kind we discussed in the introduction. Judges were informed of the presence of distractors; this served to protect themselves from the judges not recognizing only the "DE" label. We should mention that the annotation process was very time-consuming because the generalization of the number of examples we might get may be quite difficult.
